Windsor''''', {{scite|570|___|2013}} (Docket No. {{SupremeCourtDocket|12|307}}),<!-- Docket No. can probably be removed once a full SC citation is available --> is a [[List of landmark court decisions in the United States|landmark]] case<ref name="NBCNews20130627" /><ref name="NYT20130627" /><ref name="Mears20130627" /> in which the [[Supreme Court of the United States|United States Supreme Court]] held that restricting U.S. federal interpretation of "marriage" and "spouse" to apply only to [[heterosexual]] unions, by Section 3 of the [[Defense of Marriage Act]] (DOMA), is unconstitutional under the [[Due Process Clause]] of the [[Fifth Amendment to the United States Constitution|Fifth Amendment]]; [[Justice Kennedy]] wrote: "The federal statute is invalid, for no legitimate purpose overcomes the purpose and effect to disparage and to injure those whom the State, by its marriage laws, sought to protect in personhood and dignity."<ref>[http://www.newyorker.com/news/news-desk/how-the-court-ruled-on-doma-and-prop-8 How The Court Ruled on DOMA and Prop. 8, by Richard Socarides, The New Yorker, June 26, 2013]</ref>
Edith Windsor (born 1929) and Thea Spyer, a [[same-sex couple]] residing in [[New York]], were lawfully married in [[Ontario]], Canada, in 2007. Spyer died in 2009, leaving her entire [[Estate (law)|estate]] to Windsor. Windsor sought to claim the federal [[Inheritance tax|estate tax]] [[Tax exemption|exemption]] for [[Widow|surviving spouse]]s. She was barred from doing so by Section 3 of DOMA (codified at {{usc|1|7}}), which provided that the term "spouse" only applied to marriages between a man and woman. The [[Internal Revenue Service]] found that the exemption did not apply to [[Same-sex marriage in the United States|same-sex marriage]]s, denied Windsor's claim, and compelled her to pay $363,053 in estate taxes.
On November 9, 2010, Windsor filed a lawsuit against the federal government in the [[U.S. District Court for the Southern District of New York]], seeking a refund because DOMA singled out legally married same-sex couples for "differential treatment compared to other similarly situated couples without justification."<ref>{{cite web|title=Complaint: Windsor v. United States |url=http://www.aclu.org/files/assets/2010-11-9-WindsorvUS-Complaint.pdf| publisher=aclu.org |accessdate=June 27, 2013|page=21}}</ref> On February 23, 2011, U.S. Attorney General [[Eric Holder]] announced that the DOJ would not defend the constitutionality of Section 3 in ''Windsor''. On April 18, 2011, [[Paul Clement]], representing the [[Bipartisan Legal Advisory Group]] (BLAG), intervened to defend the law. On June 6, 2012, Judge [[Barbara S. Jones]] ruled that Section 3 of DOMA was unconstitutional under the due process guarantees of the Fifth Amendment and ordered the federal government to issue the tax refund, including interest. The [[United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit|U.S. Second Circuit Court of Appeals]] affirmed the decision on October 18, 2012.
BLAG petitioned the [[U.S. Supreme Court]] to review the decision, and the Court issued a [[writ]] of [[certiorari]] in December 2012. On March 27, 2013, the court heard oral arguments. On June 26, 2013, the U.S. Supreme Court issued a 5–4 decision declaring Section 3 of DOMA to be unconstitutional "as a deprivation of the liberty of the person protected by the Fifth Amendment."<ref name="Opinion">''United States v. Windsor'', {{ussc|570||June 26, 2013|docket=12-307}}. Retrieved June 26, 2013.</ref>{{rp|25}}
On the same day, the court also issued a separate 5–4 decision in ''[[Hollingsworth v. Perry]]'' — a case related to [[California Proposition 8|California's constitutional amendment initiative barring same-sex marriage]]. The decision effectively allowed [[same-sex marriage in California|same-sex marriages in that state]] to resume after the court ruled that the proponents of the initiative lacked [[Article III]] [[standing (law)|standing]] to appeal in federal court based on its established interpretation of the [[case or controversy clause]].
==Background== Edith "Edie" Windsor (née Schlain) was born in [[Philadelphia]] on June 20, 1929, to a [[Russian Jew]]ish immigrant family of modest means.<ref name="Forward">{{cite news |url=http://forward.com/specials/forward-50-2013/edith-windsor/ |title=Forward 50 (2013): Edith Windsor |author=Naomi Zeveloff |publisher=''The Forward'' |accessdate=2014-10-23 }}</ref> During her childhood, her father lost both his candy-and-ice-cream store and his house during the [[Great Depression]],<ref name="Amended">[https://stanford.app.box.com/s/qpihsz3m4giioisu3uv0 Windsor Amended Complaint]</ref> and at times she experienced [[anti-Semitism]].<ref name="Time">{{cite news |url=http://poy.time.com/2013/12/11/runner-up-edith-windsor-the-unlikely-activist/ |title=Edith Windsor, The Unlikely Activist |author=Eliza Gray |publisher=''Time'' |date=2013-12-11 }}</ref> After graduating from [[Temple University]], she married Saul Windsor. They divorced less than one year afterward,<ref name="Reveling">{{cite news |url=http://www.nytimes.com/2012/12/11/nyregion/edith-windsor-gay-widow-revels-in-supreme-court-fight.html?pagewanted=all |title=Reveling in Her Supreme Court Moment |author=Peter Applebome |publisher=''The New York Times'' |date=2012-12-10 }}</ref> and she confided in him that she longed to be with women.<ref name="Time"/> Edie Windsor soon moved to New York City to pursue a master’s degree in mathematics at [[New York University]]. She would eventually become one of the first female senior systems programmers at [[IBM]].<ref name="Forward"/>
Thea Clara Spyer was born in [[Amsterdam]] on October 8, 1931, to a wealthy Jewish family that soon escaped [[the Holocaust]] by fleeing to the United States before the [[Battle of the Netherlands|Nazi invasion of Holland]].<ref name="Forward"/><ref name="Amended"/> Spyer enrolled at [[Sarah Lawrence College]], but was expelled after a campus guard saw her and another woman kissing.<ref name="Amended"/><ref name="Time"/> She received a bachelor's degree from the [[New School for Social Research]], and both a master’s degree and a PhD in [[clinical psychology]], from [[City University of New York]] and [[Adelphi University]], respectively.<ref name="Announcement">{{cite news|title=Thea Spyer and Edith Windsor|url=http://www.nytimes.com/2007/05/27/fashion/weddings/27spyer.html|accessdate=January 1, 2013|newspaper=[[The New York Times]]|date=May 27, 2007}}</ref> In addition to her private psychology practice in Manhattan, Spyer was an accomplished violinist. She met Windsor in 1963 at a West Village restaurant,<ref name="Reveling"/> and the two began dating after they reconnected in [[the Hamptons]] during Memorial Day weekend of 1965.<ref>[http://liblog.law.stanford.edu/united-states-v-windsor/ Windsor v. U.S./U.S. v. Windsor Timeline] Robert Crown Law Library Blog</ref> Spyer proposed to her in 1967, but presented her with a diamond broach instead of an engagement ring, fearing that Windsor would be stigmatized at work if her colleagues knew about her relationship.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.washingtonpost.com/lifestyle/style/edie-windsors-fight-for-same-sex-marriage-rights-continues-even-after-partners-death/2012/07/19/gJQARguhwW_story.html |title=Edie Windsor’s fight for same-sex marriage rights continues, even after partner’s death |author=Manuel Roig-Franzia |publisher=''The Washington Post'' |date=2012-07-19 }}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.usatoday.com/story/news/nation/2012/12/07/edie-windsor-gay-marriage-supreme-court/1737387/ |title=Gay marriage case: A long time coming for Edie Windsor |author=Richard Wolf |publisher=''USA Today'' |date=2012-12-08 }}</ref>
In 2007, the pair, both residents of New York, married in [[Toronto]], Ontario, under the provisions set forth in the [[Canadian family law#Marriage|Canadian]] [[Civil Marriage Act]], after 40 years of romantic partnership.<ref>{{cite news|last=Shapiro|first=Lila|title=Edie Windsor vs. DOMA: 83-Year-Old Lesbian Petitions U.S. Supreme Court To Hear Case|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2012/07/16/edie-windsor-doma_n_1675983.html|accessdate=July 30, 2012|newspaper=[[The Huffington Post]]|date=July 16, 2012}}</ref> Canada's first openly gay judge, Justice [[Harvey Brownstone]], officiated.<ref name="Announcement"/> Windsor had first suggested engagement in 1965.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://abcnews.go.com/US/wireStory/ny-plaintiff-gay-benefits-bigger-marriage-18095217#.UOGYuiZGJ5T|agency=Associated Press|publisher=[[ABC News]]|date=December 30, 2012|title=NY Plaintiff: Gay Benefits 'Bigger Than Marriage'|last=Neumeister|first=Larry|accessdate=December 31, 2012|quote=It was not until the spring of 1965 that they got together. Windsor suggested they date for a year and consider engagement for another year if that went well.}}</ref> After Spyer's death in 2009, Windsor was required to pay $363,053 in federal estate taxes on her inheritance of her wife's estate. Had federal law recognized the validity of their marriage, Windsor would have qualified for an unlimited spousal deduction and paid no federal estate taxes.<ref>{{cite news|last=Schwartz|first=John|title=Gay Couple to Sue over U.S. Marriage Law|date=November 8, 2010 |newspaper=[[The New York Times]]|url=http://www.nytimes.com/2010/11/09/us/09marriage.html|accessdate=July 16, 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=Johnson|first=Chris|title=Two New Lawsuits Target DOMA|url=http://www.washingtonblade.com/2010/11/09/two-new-lawsuits-target-doma|accessdate=July 16, 2012|newspaper=[[Washington Blade]]|date=November 9, 2010}}</ref>
In May 2008, New York Governor [[David Paterson]] had ordered state agencies to recognize same-sex marriages performed in other jurisdictions. Some lower-level state courts had made similar rulings, but whether the state's [[New York State Court of Appeals|highest court]] would give such a ruling the force of law, as Windsor's claim for a refund required, remained uncertain<ref>{{cite news|last=Peters |first=Jeremy W.|title=New York to Back Same-Sex Unions From Elsewhere|url=http://www.nytimes.com/2008/05/29/nyregion/29marriage.html|accessdate=July 20, 2013|newspaper=New York Times|date=May 29, 2008}}</ref> and was disputed throughout her lawsuit.
Windsor at first asked several gay rights advocacy groups to represent her, but none would take the case. Finally, she was referred to [[Roberta A. Kaplan|Roberta Kaplan]], a partner at the law firm of [[Paul, Weiss, Rifkind, Wharton & Garrison LLP]], who later recalled: "When I heard her story, it took me about five seconds, maybe less, to agree to represent her". Kaplan had unsuccessfully represented the plaintiffs in a 2006 case that challenged the inability of same-sex couples to marry under New York law, ''Hernández v. Robles''.<ref>{{cite news |author=[[Peter Applebome|Applebome, Peter]] |title=Reveling in Her Supreme Court Moment|url=http://www.nytimes.com/2012/12/11/nyregion/edith-windsor-gay-widow-revels-in-supreme-court-fight.html|accessdate=December 13, 2012|newspaper=[[The New York Times]]|date=December 10, 2012}}</ref> Both Kaplan and Windsor were members of [[Congregation Beit Simchat Torah]].<ref>{{cite news |url=Edith Windsor Gets Jewish Hero's Welcome at Shul After Gay Marriage Win |publisher=''Jewish Telegraphic Agency'' via ''The Forward'' |date=2013-07-02 }}</ref>
===District Court=== Paul, Weiss, Rifkind, Wharton & Garrison, in conjunction with the [[American Civil Liberties Union]] (ACLU), filed the case in the [[United States District Court for the Southern District of New York|U.S. District Court for the Southern District of New York]] on behalf of Windsor as executor of Spyer's estate on November 9, 2010.<ref>[http://www.aclu.org/lgbt-rights/windsor-v-united-states-complaint ''Windsor v. United States'', Complaint]; retrieved March 1, 2011.</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=Geidner|first=Chris|title=Double Dose of DOMA Challenges|url=http://www.metroweekly.com/poliglot/2010/11/double-dose-of-doma-challenges.html|accessdate=July 18, 2013|newspaper=MetroWeekly|date=November 8, 2010}}</ref>
On February 23, 2011, Attorney General [[Eric Holder]] released a statement regarding two lawsuits challenging DOMA Section 3, ''Windsor'' and ''[[Pedersen v. Office of Personnel Management]]''. He explained that the Department of Justice (DOJ) had previously defended Section 3 of DOMA in several other lawsuits in jurisdictions where precedents required the court to use the [[rational basis review|rational basis standard]] for reviewing laws concerning sexual orientation. Since ''Windsor'' was filed in the jurisdiction of the [[U.S. Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit|Second Circuit Court of Appeals]], which had no such precedent, the DOJ had identified the proper standard of review in such cases as the more demanding "[[heightened scrutiny]]". Under that standard, it could no longer defend the constitutionality of DOMA Section 3.<ref name="HolderPressRelease">{{cite press release|url=http://www.justice.gov/opa/pr/2011/February/11-ag-222.html|title=Statement of the Attorney General on Litigation Involving the Defense of Marriage Act|date=February 23, 2011|accessdate=February 23, 2011|publisher=[[United States Department of Justice]]}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|publisher=[[Gay & Lesbian Advocates & Defenders]]|url=http://www.glad.org/current/news-detail/glad-statement-on-dojs-announcement-it-wont-defend-constitutionality-of-dom|title=GLAD Statement on DOJ's Announcement It Won't Defend Constitutionality of DOMA in ''Pedersen''|date=February 23, 2011|accessdate=February 23, 2011}}</ref><ref group="n">The administration continued enforcing the law until it was declared unconstitutional by the Supreme Court.</ref>
On April 18, 2011, [[Paul Clement]], representing the [[Bipartisan Legal Advisory Group]] of the House of Representatives (BLAG), filed a motion asking to be allowed to intervene in the suit "for the limited purpose of defending the constitutionality of Section III" of DOMA. The [[United States Department of Justice|Department of Justice]] did not oppose the motion.<ref>{{cite web|work=[[Metro Weekly]]|url=http://www.Metroweekly.com/poliglot/2011/04/house-leadership-seeks-to-inte.html|first=Chris|last=Geidner|title=House Leadership Seeks to Intervene in DOMA Case|date=April 18, 2011|accessdate=April 19, 2011}}</ref>
Windsor filed a motion for summary judgment on June 24.<ref>{{cite journal|publisher=[[Metro Weekly]]|url=http://Metroweekly.com/poliglot/MotionSJ.pdf|title=Memorandum in Support of Plaintiff's Motion for Summary Judgment|date=June 24, 2011|accessdate=August 3, 2011}}</ref> New York Attorney General [[Eric Schneiderman]] filed a brief supporting Windsor's claim on July 26, 2011, arguing that DOMA Section 3 could not survive the scrutiny used for classifications based on sex and constitutes "an intrusion on the power of the state to define marriage."<ref>{{cite web|work=Metro Weekly|first=Chris|last=Geidner|url=http://Metroweekly.com/poliglot/2011/07/new-york-attorney-general-take.html|title=New York Attorney General Takes Edith Windsor's Side in DOMA Challenge |date=July 26, 2011|accessdate=July 26, 2011}}</ref> On August 1, 2011, BLAG filed a brief opposing Windsor's motion for summary judgment on the grounds that sexual orientation is not subject to heightened scrutiny.<ref>{{cite web|work=Metro Weekly|url=http://Metroweekly.com/poliglot/2011/08/house-gop-leaders-say-court-sh.html|first=Chris|last=Geidner|title=House GOP Leaders Say Court Should Dismiss Edith Windsor's Lawsuit, Find DOMA Constitutional|date=August 2, 2011|accessdate=August 2, 2011}}</ref>
On June 6, 2012, Judge [[Barbara S. Jones]] ruled that a [[rational basis review]] of Section 3 of DOMA showed it to be unconstitutional, as it violated plaintiff's rights under the [[equal protection]] guarantees of the [[Fifth Amendment to the United States Constitution|Fifth Amendment]], and ordered that Windsor receive the tax refund due to her.<ref name=jones>{{cite court|url=http://lawprofessors.typepad.com/files/windsor_doma.pdf|format=PDF|litigants=Windsor v. United States|volume=833|reporter=F. Supp. 2d|opinion=394|court=SDNY|year=2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Katz|first=Basil|title=Defense of Marriage Act Unconstitutional: Judge|url=http://www.reuters.com/article/2012/06/06/us-usa-gaymarriage-idUSBRE8551JW20120606|publisher=[[Reuters]]|accessdate=December 10, 2012|date=June 6, 2012}}</ref> Where BLAG had argued that the Spyer-Windsor marriage was not recognized by New York law at the time of Spyer's death – a prerequisite for Windsor's claim against the IRS – Jones cited the "informal opinion letters" of the state's governor, attorney general, and comptroller to the contrary along with several opinions in New York appellate courts.<ref name=jones/> The plaintiff said afterward: "It's thrilling to have a court finally recognize how unfair it is for the government to have treated us as though we were strangers."<ref>{{cite web|work=[[Metro Weekly]]|url=http://www.Metroweekly.com/poliglot/2012/06/another-federal-judge-finds-doma-marriage-definiti.html|first=Chris|last=Geidner|title=Another Federal Judge Finds DOMA Marriage Definition Unconstitutional, Now in Widow's Case|date=June 6, 2012|accessdate=June 6, 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|work=[[The New York Times]]|url=http://www.nytimes.com/2012/06/08/nyregion/woman-says-same-sex-marriage-bias-cost-her-over-500000.html|author=[[Jim Dwyer (journalist)|Dwyer, Jim]]|title=She Waited 40 Years to Marry, Then When Her Wife Died, the Tax Bill Came|date=June 7, 2012|accessdate=June 8, 2012}}</ref>
===Court of Appeals=== Despite its approval of the ruling, the Justice Department filed a notice of appeal on June 14, 2012 to facilitate BLAG's defense of the statute.<ref>{{cite web|work=[[Metro Weekly]]|url=http://www.Metroweekly.com/poliglot/2012/06/domas-federal-definition-of-marriage-what-is-happe.html|first=Chris|last=Geidner|title=The DOMA Lawsuits: What Is Happening?|date=June 18, 2012|accessdate=June 19, 2012}}</ref> BLAG filed a motion to dismiss the DOJ's [[United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit|Second Circuit]] appeal on July 19, claiming the DOJ lacks standing because it prevailed in the District Court.<ref>{{cite web|title=Windsor v. USA – BLAG moves to dismiss DOJ appeal|url=http://www.prop8trialtracker.com/qh/windsor-v-usa-blag-moves-to-dismiss-doj-appeal|publisher=Prop 8 Trial Tracker|accessdate=July 24, 2012}}</ref> Meanwhile, Windsor's legal counsel filed a petition of [[certiorari before judgment]] with the Supreme Court on July 16, 2012, asking for the case to be considered without waiting for the Second Circuit's review, citing the plaintiff's age and health.<ref>{{cite web|work=Metro Weekly|url=http://www.Metroweekly.com/poliglot/2012/07/widow-petitions-doma-case-to-the-supreme-court.html|first=Justin|last=Snow|title=Widow Petitions DOMA Case to the Supreme Court|date=July 16, 2012|accessdate=July 16, 2012}}</ref>
The DOJ replied to BLAG's motion to dismiss, asserting: (1) its standing as an "aggrieved party", because the District Court's stay prevents the DOJ from taking steps to cease enforcement of Section 3 of DOMA; and (2) that its participation ensures consideration of the constitutional issue if the Second Circuit or the Supreme Court determines that BLAG lacks standing.<ref>''Windsor v. United States'', [http://www.scribd.com/doc/102159958/12-2335-108 "Opposition to Motion to Dismiss Appeal"], August 3, 2012; retrieved August 8, 2012.</ref>
On September 27, Chief Judge [[Dennis Jacobs]] and Judges [[Chester J. Straub]] and [[Christopher F. Droney]] heard arguments in the case.<ref>{{cite news|last=Johnson|first=Chris|title=GOP att'y strongly defends DOMA in N.Y. widow's lawsuit|url=http://www.washingtonblade.com/2012/09/27/gop-atty-strongly-defends-doma-in-n-y-widows-lawsuit|accessdate=September 28, 2012|newspaper=[[Washington Blade]]|date=September 27, 2012}}</ref> On October 18, the Second Circuit Court of Appeals upheld the lower court's ruling that Section 3 of DOMA is unconstitutional.<ref name="Reuters20121018">{{cite news|last=Baynes|first=Terry|title=Appeals court rules against Defense of Marriage Act|url=http://www.reuters.com/article/2012/10/18/us-usa-gaymarriage-appeal-idUSBRE89H12L20121018|accessdate=October 18, 2012|publisher=[[Reuters]]|date=October 18, 2012}}</ref><ref name=2ndcircuit>{{cite court|url=http://www.ca2.uscourts.gov/decisions/isysquery/436f323b-5e40-411a-9026-98fa59ffb645/1/doc/12-2335_complete_opn.pdf|format=PDF|litigants=Windsor v. United States|volume=699|reporter=F.3d|opinion=169|court=2d Cir.|year=2012}}</ref> The majority opinion stated, "It is easy to conclude that homosexuals have suffered a history of discrimination." Thus they were part of a [[Suspect classification#Quasi-suspect class|quasi-suspect class]] that deserves any law restricting its rights to be subjected to [[intermediate scrutiny]]. Because DOMA could not pass that test, Judge Jacobs wrote, it is unconstitutional under the equal protection guarantees of the Fifth Amendment.<ref name="Reuters20121018"/><ref>{{cite news|last=Schwartz|first=John|title=U.S. Marriage Act Is Unfair to Gays, Court Panel Says|url=http://www.nytimes.com/2012/10/19/us/appeals-court-rules-against-defense-of-marriage-act.html|accessdate=December 13, 2012|newspaper=[[The New York Times]]|date=October 18, 2012}}</ref>
:"Our straightforward legal analysis sidesteps the fair point that same-sex marriage is unknown to history and tradition, but law (federal or state) is not concerned with holy matrimony. Government deals with marriage as a civil status—however fundamental—and New York has elected to extend that status to same-sex couples." <ref name="cassens"/>
It was the first federal court of appeals decision to hold that laws that classify people based on [[sexual orientation]] should be subject to heightened scrutiny.<ref name="cassens">{{cite news|last=Weiss|first=Debra Cassens|title=2nd Circuit Rules for Surviving Gay Spouse, Says DOMA Violates Equal Protection Clause|url=http://www.abajournal.com/news/article/2nd_circuit_rules_for_surviving_gay_spouse_seeking_estate_tax_deduction_in_|accessdate=October 18, 2012|work=ABA Journal|date=October 18, 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Kemp|first=David|title=The End of an Unjust Law: The Second Circuit Strikes Down DOMA and Sets the Stage for Supreme Court Review|url=http://verdict.justia.com/2012/10/22/the-end-of-an-unjust-law|publisher=Justia|date=October 22, 2012|accessdate=December 11, 2012}}</ref> Like the lower court, the Second Circuit held that the Spyer-Windsor marriage was valid under New York law, citing precedents on that question from several state appellate court decisions, two of which preceded Spyer's death.<ref name=2ndcircuit/>
===Supreme Court=== [[File:View of Supreme Court on June 26, 2013.JPG|thumb|right|Photo of the steps of the United States Supreme Court building on the morning of June 26, 2013, hours before the court overturned the Defense of Marriage Act.]] On September 11, 2012, following Windsor's petition for certiorari before judgment and before the Second Circuit's ruling, the Department of Justice filed its own petition for [[certiorari]] before judgment with the Supreme Court.<ref>[http://www.scribd.com/doc/105738696/12-307-1-DOJ-Petition Petition for Certiorari (No 12-307).] ; retrieved December 8, 2012.</ref> After the appellate ruling on October 18, the parties filed supplemental briefs.<ref name="docket 12-307">[http://www.supremecourt.gov/Search.aspx?FileName=/docketfiles/12-307.htm Docket report for ''United States v. Windsor'' (12–307)]. Retrieved December 7, 2012.</ref> On December 7, the Supreme Court granted [[certiorari]] in the case, now ''United States v. Windsor'', accepting the DOJ's petition.
In addition to the question presented by the DOJ – "Whether Section 3 of DOMA violates the Fifth Amendment's guarantee of equal protection" for same sex partners – the court also asked the parties to brief and argue two other questions: whether the government's agreement with the Second Circuit's decision deprived the court of a "real dispute" and therefore of jurisdiction to hear the case, and whether BLAG had [[standing (law)|standing]] in its own right, i.e., the legal right to independently ask for the appeal to be heard in the event that the government was not a valid petitioner. [[Article III of the United States Constitution|Article III]] of the [[United States Constitution|Constitution]] (the "[[Case or Controversy clause]]") forbids parties that do not themselves have a ''real'' and ''personal'' ("particularized") complaint from filing a case or appeal in a federal court.<ref>{{cite web|title=Order List|url=http://www.supremecourt.gov/orders/courtorders/120712zr_3f14.pdf|publisher=United States Supreme Court|accessdate=December 8, 2012| date=December 7, 2012}}</ref>
Windsor noted in a statement that when she and her partner met nearly 50 years earlier that they never dreamed their marriage would land before the Supreme Court "as an example of why gay married couples should be treated equally, and not like second-class citizens." Noting that her deceased wife would be proud, Windsor added, "The truth is, I never expected any less from my country."<ref name="WP20121207">{{cite news|last=Barnes|first=Robert|title=Supreme Court to hear same-sex marriage cases|url=http://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/supreme-court-to-hear-same-sex-marriage-cases/2012/12/07/4bf6c366-40ab-11e2-ae43-cf491b837f7b_story.html|accessdate=December 8, 2012|newspaper=[[The Washington Post]]|date=December 7, 2012}}</ref>
On December 11, the Supreme Court appointed [[Vicki C. Jackson]], a professor of constitutional law at [[Harvard Law School]], as an ''[[amicus curiae]]'' to argue the two additional questions it posed.<ref>{{cite web|title=Order List|url=http://sblog.s3.amazonaws.com/wp-content/uploads/2012/12/Jackson-apptment-in-12-3071.docx|publisher=[[Supreme Court of the United States]]|accessdate=December 11, 2012|date=December 11, 2012}}</ref> BLAG filed its own petition for certiorari,<ref group=n>''Bipartisan Legal Advisory Group of the United States House of Representatives v. Windsor'', Docket No. [http://www.supremecourt.gov/Search.aspx?FileName=/docketfiles/12-785.htm 12-785], (U.S. Supreme Court, December 28, 2012).</ref> in order to enable the court to rule on the constitutionality of DOMA, even if it were to decide that it lacked jurisdiction to hear the DOJ's petition.<ref>{{cite news|last=Geidner|first=Chris|title=House Republican Leaders Want This To Be The Last Fight Over DOMA|url=http://www.buzzfeed.com/chrisgeidner/house-republicans-want-this-to-be-the-last-fight-o|accessdate=January 2, 2013|publisher=[[BuzzFeed]]|date=January 2, 2013}}</ref> The Supreme Court heard oral arguments on March 27, 2013.<ref>{{cite web|title=United States, Petitioner v. Edith Schlain Windsor, in Her Capacity as Executor of the Estate of Thea Clara Spyer, et al.|url=http://www.supremecourt.gov/Search.aspx?FileName=/docketfiles/12-307.htm|work=Docket|publisher=[[Supreme Court of the United States]]|accessdate=March 27, 2013}}</ref>
==Opinion of the Court==
===Majority opinion=== In a 5–4 decision issued on June 26, 2013, the Supreme Court found Section 3 of DOMA (codified at {{usc|1|7}}) to be unconstitutional,<ref name="NBCNews20130627">{{cite web|title=Supreme Court strikes down Defense of Marriage Act, paves way for gay marriage to resume in California|url=http://nbcpolitics.nbcnews.com/_news/2013/06/26/19151971-supreme-court-strikes-down-defense-of-marriage-act-paves-way-for-gay-marriage-to-resume-in-california?lite|publisher=NBC News|accessdate=June 29, 2013|author=Pete Williams and Erin McClam|date=June 26, 2013}}</ref><ref name="NYT20130627">{{cite news|last=Liptak|first=Adam|title=Supreme Court Bolsters Gay Marriage With Two Major Rulings|url=http://www.nytimes.com/2013/06/27/us/politics/supreme-court-gay-marriage.html|accessdate=June 29, 2013|newspaper=The New York Times|date=June 26, 2013}}</ref><ref name="Mears20130627">{{cite web|last=Mears|first=Bill|title=Supreme Court strikes down federal provision on same-sex marriage benefits|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2013/06/26/politics/scotus-same-sex-doma/index.html|publisher=CNN|accessdate=June 29, 2013|date=June 27, 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Hurley|first=Lawrence|title=Gay marriage gets big boost in two Supreme Court rulings|url=http://www.reuters.com/article/2013/06/26/us-usa-court-gaymarriage-idUSBRE95P06W20130626|work=Reuters|publisher=Reuters|accessdate=June 29, 2013|date=June 26, 2013}}</ref> "as a deprivation of the liberty of the person protected by the Fifth Amendment".<ref name="Opinion"/>{{rp|25}}<ref>{{cite news|last=Mears|first=Bill|title=Key quotes from Supreme Court ruling on Defense of Marriage Act|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2013/06/26/politics/scotus-same-sex-doma-quotes/index.html|accessdate=June 29, 2013|newspaper=CNN|date=June 27, 2013}}</ref> The Court held that the Constitution prevented the federal government from treating state-sanctioned heterosexual marriages differently than state-sanctioned same-sex marriages, and that such differentiation "demean[ed] the couple, whose moral and sexual choices the Constitution protects."<ref>See ''Windsor'', 133 S. Ct. at 2694.</ref> [[Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States|Justice]] [[Anthony Kennedy]] authored the majority opinion, joined by Justices [[Ruth Bader Ginsburg|Ginsburg]], [[Stephen Breyer|Breyer]], [[Sonia Sotomayor|Sotomayor]], and [[Elena Kagan|Kagan]].<ref name="WP20130626">{{cite news|url=http://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/supreme-court/2013/06/26/f0039814-d9ab-11e2-a016-92547bf094cc_story.html|title=Supreme Court strikes down Defense of Marriage Act|newspaper=The Washington Post|first=Robert|last=Barnes|date=June 26, 2013}}</ref> Kennedy's decision to strike down a central part of DOMA cited the principles of state autonomy, equal protection and liberty,<ref name="WP20130626"/> but the constitutional basis for striking down the law was not entirely clear, as it had elements of [[federalism]], equal protection and due process.<ref name="NYT20130627"/>
The Court wrote:<ref>{{cite news|last=Thomaston|first=Scottie|title=Analysis: Supreme Court Invalidates Section 3 of DOMA, Paving the Way for Federal Recognition of Same-Sex Marriages|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/scottie-thomaston/analysis-supreme-court-in_b_3506136.html|accessdate=June 29, 2013|newspaper=The Huffington Post|date=June 26, 2013}}</ref> [[File:Anthony Kennedy official SCOTUS portrait crop.jpg|thumb|right|190px|[[Anthony Kennedy|Justice Kennedy]], the author of the Court's opinion.]]
{{quote|DOMA seeks to injure the very class New York seeks to protect. By doing so it violates basic [[Due Process Clause|due process]] and [[Equal Protection Clause|equal protection]] principles applicable to the Federal Government. See U.S. Const., Amdt. 5; [[Bolling v. Sharpe]], 347 U.S. 497 (1954).<ref>''Windsor'', 570 U.S., at 20 (slip op.).</ref>
When New York adopted a law to permit same-sex marriage, it sought to eliminate inequality; but DOMA frustrates that objective through a system-wide enactment with no identified connection to any particular area of federal law. DOMA writes inequality into the entire United States Code. The particular case at hand concerns the estate tax, but DOMA is more than a simple determination of what should or should not be allowed as an estate tax refund. Among the over 1,000 statutes and numerous federal regulations that DOMA controls are laws pertaining to Social Security, housing, taxes, criminal sanctions, copyright, and veterans' benefits.<ref>''Windsor'', 570 U.S., at 22 (slip op.).</ref>
DOMA's principal effect is to identify a subset of state-sanctioned marriages and make them unequal. The principal purpose is to impose inequality, not for other reasons like governmental efficiency. Responsibilities, as well as rights, enhance the dignity and integrity of the person. And DOMA contrives to deprive some couples married under the laws of their State, but not other couples, of both rights and responsibilities. By creating two contradictory marriage regimes within the same State, DOMA forces same-sex couples to live as married for the purpose of state law but unmarried for the purpose of federal law, thus diminishing the stability and predictability of basic personal relations the State has found it proper to acknowledge and protect. By this dynamic DOMA undermines both the public and private significance of state-sanctioned same-sex marriages; for it tells those couples, and all the world, that their otherwise valid marriages are unworthy of federal recognition. This places same-sex couples in an unstable position of being in a second-tier marriage. The differentiation demeans the couple, whose moral and sexual choices the Constitution protects,<ref>See ''[[Lawrence v. Texas]]'', {{ussc|539|558|2003|source=f}}.</ref> ... and whose relationship the State has sought to dignify. And it humiliates tens of thousands of children now being raised by same-sex couples. The law in question makes it even more difficult for the children to understand the integrity and closeness of their own family and its concord with other families in their community and in their daily lives.<ref>''Windsor'', 570 U.S., at 22–23 (slip op.).</ref>
Under DOMA, same-sex married couples have their lives burdened, by reason of government decree, in visible and public ways. By its great reach, DOMA touches many aspects of married and family life, from the mundane to the profound. It prevents same-sex married couples from obtaining government healthcare benefits they would otherwise receive.<ref>See {{Uscsub|5|8901|5}}, {{Uscsub2|5|8905}}.</ref> ... It deprives them of the Bankruptcy Code's special protections for domestic-support obligations.<ref>See {{Uscsub|11|101|14A}}, {{Uscsub2|11|507|a|1|A}}, {{Uscsub2|11|523|a|5}}, {{Uscsub2|11|523|a|15}}.</ref> ... It forces them to follow a complicated procedure to file their state and federal taxes jointly.<ref>Technical Bulletin TB–55, 2010 Vt. Tax LEXIS 6 (October 7, 2010); Brief for Federalism Scholars as ''Amici Curiae'' 34.</ref> ... It prohibits them from being buried together in veterans' cemeteries.<ref>National Cemetery Administration Directive 3210/1, p. 37 (June 4, 2008).</ref><ref>''Windsor'', 570 U.S., at 23 (slip op.).</ref>
For certain married couples, DOMA's unequal effects are even more serious. The federal penal code makes it a crime to "assaul[t], kidna[p], or murde[r] ... a member of the immediate family" of "a United States official, a United States judge, [or] a Federal law enforcement officer,"<ref>{{uscsub|18|115|a|1|A}}.</ref> ... with the intent to influence or retaliate against that official.<ref>{{uscsub|18|115|a|1}}.</ref> ... Although a "spouse" qualifies as a member of the officer's "immediate family,"<ref>{{uscsub|18|115|c|2}}.</ref> ... DOMA makes this protection inapplicable to same-sex spouses.<ref>''Windsor'', 570 U.S., at 23–24 (slip op.).</ref>
The liberty protected by the Fifth Amendment’s Due Process Clause contains within it the prohibition against denying to any person the equal protection of the laws which equal protection guarantee of the Fourteenth Amendment makes that Fifth Amendment right all the more specific and all the better understood and preserved. The class to which DOMA directs its restrictions and restraints are those persons who are joined in same-sex marriages made lawful by the State. DOMA singles out a class of persons deemed by a State entitled to recognition and protection to enhance their own liberty. It imposes a disability on the class by refusing to acknowledge a status the State finds to be dignified and proper. DOMA instructs all federal officials, and indeed all persons with whom same-sex couples interact, including their own children, that their marriage is less worthy than the marriages of others. The federal statute is invalid, for no legitimate purpose overcomes the purpose and effect to disparage and to injure those whom the State, by its marriage laws, sought to protect in personhood and dignity. By seeking to displace this protection and treating those persons as living in marriages less respected than others, the federal statute is in violation of the Fifth Amendment.<ref>''Windsor'', 570 U.S., at 25–26 (slip op.).</ref>}}
===Dissents=== [[Chief Justice of the United States|Chief Justice]] [[John Roberts]] and Justices [[Antonin Scalia]] and [[Samuel Alito]] authored dissenting opinions, which Justice [[Clarence Thomas]] joined.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.csmonitor.com/USA/Latest-News-Wires/2013/0626/Supreme-Court-strikes-down-DOMA-and-Prop.-8-ban-on-same-sex-marriage|title=Supreme Court strikes down DOMA and Prop. 8 ban on same-sex marriage|newspaper=Christian Science Monitor|author=Mark Sherman|agency=Associated Press|date=June 26, 2013}}</ref>
Justice Scalia's dissent, which was joined in full by Justice Thomas and in part by Justice Roberts,<ref>''Windsor'', {{ussc|570||2013|docket=12-307}} (Scalia, J., dissenting slip op.).</ref> opened: {{quote|This case is about power in several respects. It is about the power of our people to govern themselves, and the power of this Court to pronounce the law. Today's opinion aggrandizes the latter, with the predictable consequence of diminishing the former. We have no power to decide this case. And even if we did, we have no power under the Constitution to invalidate this democratically adopted legislation.}} [[File:Antonin Scalia, SCOTUS photo portrait.jpg|thumb|right|190px|[[Antonin Scalia|Justice Scalia]], the author of one of the three dissenting opinions.]] He continued: {{quote|Windsor's injury was cured by the judgment in her favor. [...] What the petitioner United States asks us to do in the case before us is exactly what the respondent Windsor asks us to do: not to provide relief from the judgment below but to say that that judgment was correct. And the same was true in the Court of Appeals: Neither party sought to undo the judgment for Windsor, and so that court should have dismissed the appeal (just as we should dismiss) for lack of jurisdiction.}}
Scalia wrote that the majority opinion characterized opponents of same-sex marriage "enemies of the human race".<ref>{{cite news|title=Scalia: 'High-Handed' Kennedy Has Declared Us 'Enemies of the Human Race'|author=Tim Grieve |url=http://www.nationaljournal.com/domesticpolicy/scalia-high-handed-kennedy-has-declared-us-enemies-of-the-human-race-20130626 |newspaper=National Journal|date=June 26, 2013|accessdate=June 26, 2013}}<br/>{{cite news|title=Scalia's Blistering Dissent on DOMA|author=Tim Grieve|url=http://www.theatlantic.com/national/archive/2013/06/scalias-blistering-dissent-on-doma/277245/#comments|publisher=''The Atlantic''|date=June 26, 2013|accessdate=June 26, 2013}}</ref>
He argued that the Court's ruling would impact [[Same-sex marriage law in the United States by state|state bans on same-sex marriage]] as well: {{quote|As far as this Court is concerned, no one should be fooled; it is just a matter of listening and waiting for the other shoe.
By formally declaring anyone opposed to same-sex marriage an enemy of human decency, the majority arms well every challenger to a state law restricting marriage to its traditional definition.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.politico.com/story/2013/06/doma-decision-gay-marriage-ripple-effect-93479.html?hp=t1_3|title=The DOMA decision ripple effect|last=Gerstein|first=Josh|date=June 26, 2013|publisher=Politico.com|accessdate=July 2, 2013}}</ref>}}
Scalia concluding by saying that the Supreme Court "has cheated both sides, robbing the winners of an honest victory, and the losers of the peace that comes from a fair defeat."<ref name="Opinion"/>
The opinions of Roberts and Scalia offered different interpretations of the majority ruling. Roberts said the majority opinion was based on federalism, finding DOMA unconstitutional because the federal government was interfering with state control of marriage. He wrote: "The dominant theme of the majority opinion is that the Federal Government's intrusion into an area 'central to state domestic relations law applicable to its residents and citizens' is sufficiently 'unusual' to set off alarm bells.... [I]ts judgment is based on federalism."<ref name="Opinion"/> Scalia was uncertain whether the majority relied upon that federalism argument or based its decision on Equal Protection grounds, writing, "if this is meant to be an equal-protection opinion, it is a confusing one."<ref name="Opinion"/>
==Responses and analysis== President Obama hailed the ruling as a "victory for American democracy". On the question of how the ruling would affect bans on same-sex marriage in those states that prohibit it, Obama said: "My personal belief, but I'm speaking now as a president as opposed to as a lawyer, is that if you've been married in Massachusetts and you move someplace else, you're still married, and that under federal law you should be able to obtain the benefits of any lawfully married couple."<ref>{{cite news|title=DOMA Ruling: 'Victory for American Democracy', Obama Says|work=ABC News|first=Mary|last=Bruce|date=June 27, 2013|url=http://abcnews.go.com/blogs/politics/2013/06/doma-ruling-victory-for-american-democracy-obama-says}}</ref>
[[Laurence Tribe]], a professor of constitutional law at [[Harvard Law School]], described Scalia's response and dissent as "intemperate", "extraordinary", and "at the very least, an exercise in jurisprudential cynicism." He considered that Scalia appeared to have been unable to resist "the temptation to use the occasion to insult the Court's majority, and Justice Kennedy in particular, in essentially [[ad hominem]] ...terms."<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.scotusblog.com/2013/06/doma-prop-8-and-justice-scalias-intemperate-dissent|publisher=SCOTUSBlog|date=June 26, 2013|first=Laurence|last=Tribe|title=DOMA, Prop 8, and Justice Scalia's intemperate dissent|accessdate=July 2, 2013}}</ref>
Neil Siegel, a professor of constitutional law at [[Duke Law School]], wrote that Justice Roberts' view that the majority relied on federalism was a fallacy in that the majority did not place any weight on the federalism argument, but rather used "federalism as a waystation" to put off making a decision on the constitutionality of state laws concerning same-sex marriage.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://papers.ssrn.com/sol3/papers.cfm?abstract_id=2396179|publisher=SSRN|date=February 14, 2014|first=Neil|last=Siegel|title=Federalism as a Way Station: Windsor as Exemplar of Doctrine in Motion|accessdate=March 10, 2014}}</ref>

Nolo Law for all|accessdate=July 26, 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=John Kerry Announces Visa Changes for Same-Sex Couples|url=http://blogs.usembassy.gov/malaysia/2013/08/05/john-kerry-announces-visa-changes-for-same-sex-couples|publisher=U.S. Embassy Kuala Lumpur|accessdate=July 26, 2014|date=August 2, 2013}}</ref>
In February 2014, the [[United States Department of Justice|Justice Department]] expanded recognition of same-sex marriages in federal legal matters, including bankruptcies, prison visits, survivor benefits and the legal right to refuse to testify to incriminate a spouse.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Perez|first1=Evan|title=U.S. expands legal benefits, services for same-sex marriages|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2014/02/08/politics/holder-same-sex-marriage-rights/|publisher=CNN|accessdate=July 26, 2014|date=February 10, 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=Holder, Jr.|first1=Eric|title=Office of Attorney Memorandum to all department employees entitled ''Department Policy on Ensuring Equal Treamtment for Same-Sex Married Couples''|url=http://www.justice.gov/iso/opa/resources/9201421014257314255.pdf|publisher=U.S. Department of Justice|accessdate=July 26, 2014|date=February 10, 2014}}</ref> Likewise in June 2014, family [[medical leave]] benefits under the [[Family and Medical Leave Act of 1993]] were extended to married same-sex couples in all of the U.S.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Chappell|first1=Bill|title=Married Same-Sex Couples To Receive More Federal Benefits|url=http://www.npr.org/blogs/thetwo-way/2014/06/20/323855724/same-sex-couples-across-u-s-to-receive-broader-benefits|accessdate=July 26, 2014|work=National Public Radio|date=June 20, 2014}}</ref><ref name="Guardian20140620"/> With respect to [[social security]] and veterans benefits, same-sex married couples who live in states where same-sex marriage is recognised are eligible for full benefits from the [[United States Department of Veterans Affairs|Veterans Affairs]] (VA) and the [[Social Security Administration]] (SSA). The VA and SSA can provide only limited benefits to married same-sex couples living in states where same-sex marriage isn't legal, with [[United States Congress|Congress]] required to amend federal law to rectify that inequity.<ref name="Guardian20140620">{{cite news|last1=Glenza|first1=Jessica|title=Federal agencies roll out benefits for married same-sex couples|url=http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/jun/20/same-sex-couples-benefits-expanded-obama-administration |accessdate=July 26, 2014|work=The Guardian|publisher=The Guardian|date=June 20, 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |last1=Capehart|first1=Jonathan|title=Fix the Social Security discrepancy DOMA left behind |url=http://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/post-partisan/wp/2014/05/09/fix-the-social-security-discrepancy-doma-left-behind/|accessdate=July 26, 2014|work=The Washington Post|date=May 9, 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=Capehart|first1=Jonathan|title=Social Security agency shows why Supreme Court must act on gay marriage|url=http://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/post-partisan/wp/2014/06/23/social-security-agency-shows-why-supreme-court-must-act-on-gay-marriage|accessdate=July 26, 2014|work=The Washington Post|date=June 23, 2014}}</ref>
According to one reporter's assessment in August 2013, despite the foregoing efforts the U.S. federal agencies are not working in concert with respect to the implementation of the ''Windsor'' ruling. Instead "they are creating a patchwork of regulations affecting gay and lesbian couples — and may be raising questions about discrimination and fairness in the way that federal benefits are distributed."<ref name="NYT20130829"/>
==Judicial interpretation== <!-- DECISIONS THAT CITE WINDSOR ARE NOT INTERESTING FOR THAT REASON ALONE. LOTS DO. WHAT IS INTERESTING IS HOW THEY ***INTERPRET*** WINDSOR. FEDERALISM OR NOT FEDERALISM? WHAT LEVEL OF SCRUTINY? --> Some courts used ''Windsor'' in ways that did not address the reasoning of the decision. For example, a New Jersey state judge found that the extension of federal benefits to married same-sex couples following the ''Windsor'' decision made it obvious that New Jersey's civil unions represented a second class status.<ref>{{cite web|title=Decision on Motion for Summary Judgement |url=http://www.judiciary.state.nj.us/samesex/Decision_Summary_Judgment_and%20Order.pdf |publisher=''Garden State Equity v. Dow'', N.J. Super. Ct. Law Div., Docket MER-L-1729-11 (Sept. 27, 2013)}}</ref> In several other cases, the ambiguity in the majority decision in ''Windsor'' has produced varying interpretations in later legal decisions that address state regulation of marriage and the denial of marriage rights to same-sex couples. Courts have disputed whether ''Windsor'' relied upon federalism or equal protection and what standard of review the Supreme Court applied. Others have used it to dismiss the precedential importance of ''[[Baker v. Nelson]]''.
In December 2013, a U.S. District Court judge ruling in ''[[Kitchen v. Herbert]]'' found ''Baker'' no longer controlled his decision, because the rule is that "doctrinal developments" can obviate the importance of a dismissal like ''Baker'' and given the issues before the court ''Windsor'' was "highly relevant and is therefore a significant doctrinal development". It also read ''Windsor'' as an equal protection case, writing: "The court agrees with Justice Scalia's interpretation of Windsor and finds that the important federalism concerns at issue here are nevertheless insufficient to save a state-law prohibition that denies the Plaintiffs their rights to due process and equal protection under the law."<ref>[http://www.scribd.com/doc/192796334/Federal-Court-Decision-in-Kitchen-v-Herbert District Court Ruling]</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=Denniston|first=Lyle|title=Utah's same-sex marriage ban falls|url=http://www.scotusblog.com/2013/12/utahs-same-sex-marriage-ban-falls|accessdate=January 20, 2014|newspaper=SCOTUSblog|date=December 21, 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=McCombs|first=Brady|title=Utah Gay Marriage Ban Struck Down As Unconstitutional|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2013/12/20/utah-gay-marriage-ban_n_4482222.html |agency= Associated Press|publisher=Huffington Post|accessdate=March 11, 2014|date=December 20, 2012}}</ref>
District Court Judge [[Arenda L. Wright Allen]] ruling in ''[[Bostic v. Rainey]]'' on February 13, 2014, noted that ''Windsor'' discussed the deference due state laws defining marriage only to assert that "due process and equal protection guarantees must trump objections to federal intervention". She cited Justice Scalia's prediction that the reasoning of the majority in ''Windsor'' with respect to federal law motivated by a "bare ... desire to harm" would produce the same conclusion with respect to state laws.<ref>[http://freedomtomarry.org/page/-/files/pdfs/Bostic-Decision.pdf Bostic v. Rainey, February 13, 2014], accessed October 3, 2014</ref>
In ''[[Recognition of same-sex unions in Texas#Lawsuit|De Leon v. Perry]]'', [[Orlando Luis Garcia| Orlando Garcia]] on February 26, 2014, framed the lawsuit in terms of ''Windsor'': "Now, the lower courts must apply the Supreme Court's decision in ''Windsor'' and decide whether a state can do what the federal government cannot–discriminate against same-sex couples." He then made the same point Judge Wright Allen had made, citing ''Windsor'': "While Texas has the 'unquestioned authority' to regulate and define marriage, the State must nevertheless do so in a way that does not infringe on an individual's constitutional rights." (references omitted)<ref>{{cite web|title=Order on Preliminary Injunction|url=http://de.scribd.com/doc/209421264/5-13-cv-00982-73|work=United States District Court for the Western District of Texas |publisher= scribd.com|accessdate=October 3, 2014|author=Orlando Luis Garcia|date= February 26, 2014}}</ref>
A 3-judge panel of the [[United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit|Ninth Circuit Court of Appeals]] in ''[[SmithKline v. Abbott]]'' considered what standard of review to apply when determining whether sexual orientation can be used in selecting the members of a jury. It ruled unanimously on January 21, 2014, based on its reading of ''Windsor'', that distinctions based on sexual orientation are subject to the "heightened scrutiny" standard of review and that "equal protection prohibits peremptory strikes based on sexual orientation".<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://blogs.reuters.com/alison-frankel/2014/01/22/judges-build-on-supreme-courts-windsor-ruling-to-extend-gay-rights|title=Judges Build on Supreme Court's Windsor ruling to extend gay rights|date=January 22, 2014|first=Alison|last=Frankel|accessdate=May 22, 2014|publisher=Reuters}}</ref> The Ninth Circuit wrote:<ref>{{cite news|last=Geidner |first=Chris|title=Federal Appeals Court Says Jurors Can't Be Excluded Because They Are Gay|url=http://www.buzzfeed.com/chrisgeidner/federal-appeals-court-says-jurors-cant-be-excluded-because-t|accessdate=January 21, 2014|newspaper=Buzz Feed |date=January 21, 2014}}</ref> {{quote|''Windsor'' review is not rational basis review. In its words and its deed, ''Windsor'' established a level of scrutiny for classifications based on sexual orientation that is unquestionably higher than rational basis review. In other words, ''Windsor'' requires that heightened scrutiny be applied to equal protection claims involving sexual orientation.}} The Ninth Circuit court also observed that the majority in ''Windsor'' shifted the burden from the same-sex couple to the government when it wrote that the government has to "''justify'' disparate treatment of the group."<ref name="Thomaston">{{cite web|last=Thomaston|first=Scottie|title=Ninth Circuit Court of Appeals rules jurors can't be kept off a jury because of their sexual orientation |url=http://equalityontrial.com/2014/01/21/ninth-circuit-court-appeals-rules-jurors-cant-kept-jury-sexual-orientation |publisher=Equality on Trial|accessdate=March 11, 2014|date=January 21, 2014}}</ref>
Some courts have agreed with Scalia that the ''Windsor'' decision lacked clarity and proceeded to interpret it with little reference to federalism, just as Scalia had predicted.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.nationaljournal.com/politics/what-antonin-scalia-got-right-about-same-sex-marriage-20140520|title=What Antonin Scalia Got Right on Same-Sex Marriage|date=May 20, 2014|first=Sam|last=Baker|accessdate=May 22, 2014|publisher=NationalJournal.com}}</ref> When ruling Oklahoma's ban on same-sex marriage unconstitutional on January 14, 2014, in ''[[Bishop v. United States|Bishop v. Oklahoma]]'', U.S. District Judge [[Terence C. Kern]] described the decision as the culmination of a process: "There is no precise legal label for what has occurred in Supreme Court jurisprudence beginning with ''Romer'' in 1996 and culminating in ''Windsor'' in 2013, but this Court knows a rhetorical shift when it sees one".<ref>{{cite news |last=Geidner |first=Chris|title=Oklahoma Ban On Same-Sex Marriages Is Unconstitutional, Federal Judge Rules |url=http://www.buzzfeed.com/chrisgeidner/oklahoma-ban-on-same-sex-marriages-is-unconstitutional-judge|accessdate=January 15, 2014|newspaper=Buzz Feed |date=January 14, 2014}}</ref> When U.S. District Judge [[John E. Jones III|Jone E. Jones]] ruled on May 20, 2014, that Pennsylvania's same-sex marriage ban was unconstitutional, he read ''Windsor'' as an equal protection decision. He cited Justice Scalia's critique of the lack of clarity in the ''Windsor'' decision, writing: "As Justice Scalia cogently remarked in his dissent, 'if [''Windsor''] is meant to be an equal-protection opinion, it is a confusing one.... Windsor found DOMA unconstitutional because 'no legitimate purpose overcomes the purpose and effect to disparage and to injure.'"<ref>[http://coop.pamd.uscourts.gov/13-1861.pdf ''Whitewood v. Wolf'' - Ruling], retrieved October 2, 2014</ref>
On the other hand, U.S. District Judge [[Martin Leach-Cross Feldman|Martin Feldman]], upholding Louisiana's ban on same-sex marriage on September 3, 2014, reviewed the arguments before him and wrote: "Both sides invoke the Supreme Court's decision in United States v. Windsor.... But Windsor does little more than give both sides in this case something to hope for." In a footnote, he explained his reading of the case:<ref name=robicheaux>[http://www.scribd.com/doc/238549858/2-13-cv-05090-131 Order and reasons, ''Robicheaux v. Caldwell'', September 3, 2014], accessed October 2, 2014</ref> {{quote|Windsor, in the context of the issues presented to this Court, is unclear (contrary to the conclusions in many recent federal court decisions). It is by its own terms, limited. Its "opinion and its holding are confined to those lawful marriages." However, Windsor also references an amorphous but alluring "evolving understanding of the meaning of equality". Hence this Court's unease that Windsor merely offer bits and pieces of hope to both sides. (citations omitted)}} He quoted Chief Justice Roberts' dissent as a reason not to read ''Windsor'' as a guide for deciding the constitutionality of restrictions on same-sex marriage: "The Court does not have before it", wrote Roberts, "and the logic of its opinion does not decide the distinct question whether the States, in the exercise of their 'historic and essential authority to define the marital relation,' ... may continue to utilize the traditional definition of marriage." Feldman found nothing in ''Windsor'' to require him to use heightened scrutiny, saying that "Windsor starkly avoids mention of heightened scrutiny." He called the argument that ''Windsor'''s use of the phrase "careful consideration" meant intermediate or heightened scrutiny amounted to "intellectual anarchy". He criticized several recent federal court decisions for failing to specify the appropriate standard of review they used to evaluate the constitutionality of bans on same-sex marriage. Instead he cited ''Windsor'' for its "powerful reminder" that "'The definition of marriage is the foundation of the State's broader authority to regulate the subject of domestic relations'".<ref name=robicheaux/>
